item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Amen to all of this. A long list of recommendations for improving research integrity investigations from a group at the coalface. The list is long because current procedures are inefficient, Kafkaesque and fabulously frustrating. Even if the biggest problems are now probably caused by institutions protecting their reputations and funder apathy, it's true that COPE guidelines are a sorry mess.https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-024-02449-8

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: The suggestion to decouple evaluation of reliability from deciding who is at fault for what is a good one. I would take it further by making public the data early in an investigation. If all is well it should harm nobody's reputation. If all is not well, that would become embarrassingly clear at a much earlier stage. No data? No paper.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: I've no objection to the suggestion of minimising loaded terms like "misconduct" in journal notices, but I'm not convinced it would help a lot. Moreover, it would be good to be more systematic about getting the authors to explain in detail "what happened", both during any investigation but also in the final notice. "Inadvertent clerical mistake" is a the sort of fig leaf we often end up with to describe a manipulation that could never occur within an honest workflow.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: If COPE wish to remain relevant, they should bring in a panel of experts (those with real-world experience), like the authors of that piece and Elisabeth Bik, to create a unified, robust procedure for responding to and processing reports of problems in papers.For instance, Bik's classification of image problems is definitely (and unsurprisingly) more useful than COPE's.

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: @BorisBarbour @Dalmeet In order: No; they have one already and this seems to be the same thing but just without the peer review bit; unclear; probably but the notion one can have a single set of verifications appropriate to all article types seems improbably nor could one do this in a timely fashion, which is why IMO decoupling at least some of these might be better (IOW biorxiv/medrxiv will do verificationsit is feasible/practical/economical to do but probably not everything some would want).
